questions.title: Yield and Yield Spread Measures for Fixed Rate Bonds
questions.question:
Consider a $100 par value bond with an 8% coupon paid annually, maturing in 20 years. If the bond currently sells for $96.47, the yield to maturity is closest to:

  1. 7.41%.
  2. 8.29%.
  3. 8.37%.
questions.explanation: Solution Incorrect because it is: $8/$108 = 0.0741. Incorrect because it is the securityâ€™s current yield: ($8/$96.47). Correct. A security with a present value of 96.47, 19 interest payments of 8, and a 20th payment of principal plus interest (108) has a yield to maturity of 8.37%. questions.solution_html:
Solution

  1. Incorrect because it is: $8/$108 = 0.0741.

  2. Incorrect because it is the securityâ€™s current yield: ($8/$96.47).

  3. Correct. A security with a present value of 96.47, 19 interest payments of 8, and a 20th payment of principal plus interest (108) has a yield to maturity of 8.37%.

questions.question:
Stellar Corp. recently issued $100 par value deferred coupon bonds, which will make no coupon payments in the next four years. Regular annual coupon payments at a rate of 8% will then be made until the bonds mature at the end of 10 years. If the bonds are currently priced at $87.00, their yield to maturity is closest to:

  1. 6.0%.
  2. 8.0%.
  3. 10.1%.
questions.explanation: Solution Correct. The yield to maturity ( r ) is computed by solving for r in the following equation: 87.00 = 8/(1 + r ) 5 + 8/(1 + r ) 6 + 8/(1 + r ) 7 + 8/(1 + r ) 8 + 8/(1 + r ) 9 + 108/(1 + r ) 10 which gives a yield to maturity of 6.0%. Incorrect because the yield to maturity is computed by treating the bond as a ten-year, coupon-paying bond with a price of $100 and solving for r in the following expression: 100.00 = 8/(1 + r ) 1 + 8/(1 + r ) 2 + â€¦ + 8/(1 + r ) 9 + 108/(1 + r ) 10 Incorrect because the yield to maturity is computed by treating the bond like a ten-year bond and solving for r in the following expression: 87.00 = 8/(1 + r ) 1 + 8/(1 + r ) 2 + â€¦ + 8/(1 + r ) 9 + 108/(1 + r ) 10 Yield and Yield Spread Measures for Fixed-Rate Bonds compare, calculate, and interpret yield and yield spread measures for fixed-rate bonds

questions.question:
An analyst is analyzing a three-year, 2.25% annual coupon bond issued by QWE Company. Currently, the bondâ€™s yield-to-maturity is 2.707%. The three-year swap rate is 1.840%. The government spot rates are presented in the table.

Maturity Government Spot Rate
1Y 0.899%
2Y 1.260%
3Y 1.904%

The G-Spread (in basis points) for the QWE bond is closest to:
questions.explanation: Solution A is correct. The G-spread is a yield spread above that of a government bond with the same maturity date. The yield-to-maturity for the corporate bond is 2.7070%. The yield-to-maturity for the government benchmark bond is 1.9036%. G-spread = 2.707% â€“ 1.904% = 0.8034% = 80.3 bps. B is incorrect because 87 bps is the I-spread calculated as the yield spread of a bond over the standard swap rate in the same currency and with the same tenor. C is incorrect because 135 bps is the spread calculated as the difference between the yield-to-maturity of the QWE bond and the average of government rates for all maturities.
questions.solution_html:
Solution

A is correct. The G-spread is a yield spread above that of a government bond with the same maturity date. The yield-to-maturity for the corporate bond is 2.7070%. The yield-to-maturity for the government benchmark bond is 1.9036%.

G-spread = 2.707% â€“ 1.904% = 0.8034% = 80.3 bps.

B is incorrect because 87 bps is the I-spread calculated as the yield spread of a bond over the standard swap rate in the same currency and with the same tenor.

C is incorrect because 135 bps is the spread calculated as the difference between the yield-to-maturity of the QWE bond and the average of government rates for all maturities.

questions.title: Yield and Yield Spread Measures for Fixed Rate Bonds
questions.question:
The factor least likely to influence the yield spread on an option-free, fixed-rate bond is a change in the:

  1. liquidity of the bond.
  2. expected inflation rate.
  3. credit risk of the issuer.
questions.explanation: Solution Incorrect because changes in the yield spread an option-free, fixed-rate bond arise from changes in the liquidity of the issue. Correct because for an option-free, fixed-rate bond, changes in the yield spread can arise from changes in the credit risk of the issuer and/or changes in the liquidity of the issue. Changes in the expected inflation rate influence the benchmark rate. Incorrect because changes in the yield spread an option-free, fixed-rate bond arise from changes in the credit risk of the issuer. Yield and Yield Spread Measures for Fixed-Rate Bonds compare, calculate, and interpret yield and yield spread measures for fixed-rate bonds
questions.solution_html:
Solution

  1. Incorrect because changes in the yield spread an option-free, fixed-rate bond arise from changes in the liquidity of the issue.

  2. Correct because for an option-free, fixed-rate bond, changes in the yield spread can arise from changes in the credit risk of the issuer and/or changes in the liquidity of the issue. Changes in the expected inflation rate influence the benchmark rate.

  3. Incorrect because changes in the yield spread an option-free, fixed-rate bond arise from changes in the credit risk of the issuer.
